user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemTake_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemTake_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Lock the mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&(impl->id));
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemTake_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_MutSemTake(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_mutex_internal_record_t *mutex;
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        mutex = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_mutex_table, token);

        return_code = OS_MutSemTake_Impl(&token);
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* Always set the owner if OS_MutSemTake_Impl() returned success */
            mutex->last_owner = OS_TaskGetId();
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. Analysis of the provided code and related definitions shows no direct or indirect self-calls for the functions involved:

- OS_MutSemTake_Impl calls pthread_mutex_lock and uses the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro to index the OS_impl_mutex_table. pthread_mutex_lock is a POSIX API and does not call back into the OS_* functions shown here.
- The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro expands to use OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok)), and the inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken only returns token->obj_idx and makes no function calls.
- OS_MutSemTake calls OS_MutSemTake_Impl (one-way); there is no call from OS_MutSemTake_Impl back to OS_MutSemTake or any other function in the provided code that would form a cycle.
- OS_impl_mutex_table is a data array and does not introduce function calls.

Given the supplied code and related symbols, there is no evidence of a function calling itself directly or indirectly, so no fragments require further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
